events.name: IBM | Spark Signature Moment Singapore Event
events.description: IBM is placing its biggest bet on open source innovation since we led the adoption of Linux through hundreds of business solutions. We are announcing our commitment to Apache Spark, an in-memory compute engine that delivers eye-opening speed and flexibility to data scientists and developers working with big data at scale. In fact, we are bringing the speed, agility and power of Spark into our Analytics Platform to make sure we're meeting the emerging needs of data-driven enterprises. After our initial launch we will be hosting a regional Spark Signature Moment Event in Singapore on Thursday July 2, 2015 Join Us for an Update & Lunch to Learn About IBM’s Commitment to Open Source & Spark Innovation Agenda: Reception and introductions by IBM regional Executive Highlights from IBM Signature Moment Round Table in San Francisco Presentation: o The use cases for Big Data platform and the benefits of Apache Spark o IBM’s innovations for Apache Spark, hybrid architecture o Open Data Platform (ODP) o IBM’s Analytics Platform for Apache Spark Lunch Check us out at: ibm.co/ibmspark RSVP by June 25th – LIMITED SEATING
events.location: IBM Client Centre, No.6 Tampines Industrial Ave 5 ,Singaore 528760, Singapore

events.name: Algorithms used in Games: Any-Angle Path Finding in Open Spaces
events.description: The answer to finding the shortest path between two points on a graph is well-known. However, strategy games and other real-life cases often involve wide-open spaces without well-defined graphs, how does one construct shortest paths between arbitrary points in a space? We give an overview of the most effective algorithms for generating realistic paths using a grid-based approximation of open spaces. Oh Shunhao is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at NUS. He enjoys mathematical problems and algorithms, and loves sharing about them with like-minded people. He also makes games in his spare time. He is currently working with Health Visuals to produce a game for the app store. His current research work involves working on finding fast any-angle pathfinding algorithms for use in games, as well as developing cool visualisations for them.
events.location: Plug-In@Blk71

events.name: Angular and JHipster night!
events.description: Hi, location is now confirmed. We will host our event at Paypal (Suntec tower). Michael Isvy - Migrating a JSP application to AngularJS Why are so many people moving to AngularJS? Is it a suitable choice for all Java applications? Does it add complexity to your project? Michael will walk you through a step by step migration from JSP to AngularJS. Deepu K Sasidharan - JHispter Deepu is one of the JHipster contributors and we are honored to have him at the Spring User Group. He will walk you through the JHipster core features, do a hands-on demo and will provide feedback on building a real enterprise application using JHipster.

He will speak about Release planning in Scrum Projects, various Release rhythms based on different Agile methods and also how to use relative estimation at a Project /Release level. Agenda: 7:00pm - Release Planning using Feature points 8:00pm - O&A Getting There Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 2 is just right above of Downtown station along Downtown Line (DT) .

events.name: The Future of User Experience
events.description: The digital world is at an inflection point and the implications demand that organizations hire designers who are smart generalists. Think about the moment we’re in: mobile, big data and personalization are converging to drive truly novel user experiences across countless new channels and in real life. In this post-screen world, the lines between the physical and the digital blur. It’s a world of experiences, less and less dependent on any one platform, device, interface or technology. Join us on Wednesday, July 8th, for drinks, snacks, and a presentation by VP, User Experience at Huge, Josh Payton, about how the user experience discipline has evolved alongside the digital industry and what implications this has for the future. Location: Huge's office is located at 33 Ann Siang Rd., Suite 31A. When you arrive, please check in with staff at the main building entrance and we'll send you up to the event venue. About the Speaker Josh Payton is VP of User Experience in Huge's European offices, partnering with Huge’s global strategy, design and development teams in the creation and rapid prototyping of concepts, ecosystems, and interfaces. Josh has worked for such clients as Turkish Airlines, Lowe’s, Four Seasons, Amex, Disney and many more in Huge's Brooklyn, Los Angeles and London offices. During his decade-plus of interactive design experience, Josh has acted as the User Experience Design Lead for the home and storefront pages at Amazon.com and as a Senior Designer for Microsoft, Washington Post/Newsweek Interactive and Yahoo! News.
events.location: Huge Singapore, 33 Ann Siang Rd, Suite 31A

New electronic instruments are altered in real time, fusing effortlessly with the human voice. Projected against this kaleidoscope of sound will be stunning pre-recorded images of Singapore, tying in sounds from humanity to the technology of our modern world, crossing time and space. Original production generously supported by the National Arts Council. Entry is complimentary and on a first come first served basis.

An introduction to Azure Key Vault using HSM (Hardware Security Module). Do you know that Azure has this service? • And some other cool security related stuff in Azure. events.name: Free C# Training (Beginners) For Non .NET Developers
events.description: Hi All, The .NET Developers Community would like invite YOU - regardless whether you are a C# developer or not - to join our FREE TRAINING on C# . As you may know, .NET is now OPEN SOURCE , and this is a great opportunity to learn the C# language. C# is used today in many enterprise and consumer applications. You can build almost any kind of application using C# on all platforms and all devices such as Windows , Linux and Mac . You can also build web applications using C# which can be deployed on Windows , Linux and Mac with the same code. Code once for all platforms. Maximum number of participants is 60. Closing RSVP will be Monday, July 13, 5 PM. If you don't want to miss this event, than please RSVP as early as possible and as a special bonus, there will be a free Golden Village movie ticket for the first 40 participants who RSVP and join the event until finish and fill a survey form onsite. Here are the subjects that you will learn: • Getting Started. C# Projects, Namespaces and file types. • Understanding Expressions, Types, Nullable Types, and Variables. • Control Statements – Selection and Loops. • Properties, Methods and Functions. • Introduction to Object Oriented Programming (OOP). • Understanding Class and Class Inheritance. • Polymorphism and Encapsulation. • Understanding Interfaces. • Introduction to Delegates and Events. • Using Attributes. • Introduction to Arrays and Generic Collections. • Introduction to LINQ. • Introduction to Exception Handling. PREREQUISITES If you would like to code along during the session, please bring your own Windows laptop with Visual Studio 2015 RC (Community Edition or above) installed . Unfortunately, we won't have time during the session to setup Visual Studio, so please make sure your laptop has Visual Studio 2015 RC installed beforehand. GOODIES For the first 40 participants who RSVP and JOIN the event until finish and fill a survey form onsite, we will give you a FREE GOLDEN VILLAGE MOVIE TICKET . Also we will be giving away some limited amount of free goodies such as Sandisk USB thumb drive and Starbucks Card. See you there! FACILITIES • Wi-Fi: Available (free) • Lunch and Coffee Break: Available (free)
events.location: 22CF12, Level 22, Microsoft Singapore, Singapore 018989, One Marina Boulevard

events.name: AWS First Tuesday - July Meet up
events.description: I'm pleased to announce that we will be holding our next AWS User Group meetup here in the AWS Singapore office on Tuesday 14th July. Despite the name being 'First Tuesday', this meetup will actually be on the second Tuesday in July (which is 14th July). Expect a similar format to the last couple of meetups, we will be hosting here in the AWS Singapore office again, kicking off at 7pm, Pizza and refreshments will be served. Talks will begin at 7.30pm and run for about 80 minutes. We aim to keep them short at no more than 20 minutes each. WHAT: 7.00 pm - Pizza and refreshments 7.30 pm - Chris Hampartsoumian, AWS Welcome. I will be publishing the talk titles and schedule on this page closer to the event, but we've got plenty in store - but potentially still some open slots of you'd like to present at this User Group meetup or any future event. Do get in contact with me, Chris Hampartsoumian. We're looking forward to seeing you at the meetup! WHERE: The AWS Singapore office. https://goo.gl/maps/UzzR2 WHO CAN ATTEND: All are welcome! No prior experience needed. • Anyone who wants to know more about cloud computing and startup companies • Anyone who wants to understand the benefits of cloud computing and how to use the “cloud” to benefit their organization. • Startup founders and aspiring founders COST: Free! Snacks will be served!
events.location: AWS Offices Singapore, 23 Church Street, Capital Square, #10-01, Singapore - 049481, +65-67220300

events.name: Data Mining With R (Workshop II)
events.description: Hello everyone, here are the details for our second workshop on data mining. It will be on Random Forests, and our speaker will be Toh Wei Zhong. About : Random Forests are built up from classification / regression trees. By randomly selecting predictors and creating an ensemble of trees (i.e. the forest), we are able to greatly increase the predictive capability of the method. In this talk, Wei Zhong will go into the details of the methodology, starting with the terminology all the way up to tuning the hyperparameters. We will end the workshop with a code walkthrough. About Wei Zhong: Wei Zhong is a graduate from the computational biology department at NUS. An ardent R user, he currently works as a data scientist at NCS. Slides are available on github in the random_forest folder: https://github.com/singator/rugs
events.location: NTUC Auditorium, One Marina Boulevard, No 1, Marina Boulevard, Singapore

events.name: Papers We Love #011
events.description: Paper #1: On computable numbers, with an application to the Entscheidungsproblem : Melvin Zhang - http://www.cs.virginia.edu/~robins/Turing_Paper_1936.pdf Paper #2: Oberon System Implemented on a Low-Cost FPGA Board : Michał - http://www.xilinx.com/publications/archives/xcell/Xcell91.pdf ------------------- What was the last paper within the realm of computing/technology you read and loved? What did it inspire you to build or tinker with? Come share the ideas in an awesome academic/research paper with fellow engineers, programmers, and paper-readers. Lead a session and show off code that you wrote that implements these ideas or just give us the lowdown about the paper (because of HARD MATH!). Otherwise, just come, listen, and discuss. ----------------- Original Meetup : http://www.meetup.com/papers-we-love Papers Repo : https://github.com/papers-we-love/papers-we-love Code of Conduct : https://github.com/papers-we-love/papers-we-love/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

events.name: Humla Workshop -  Advanced Application Security Testing with Burp Pro
events.description: We are pleased to inform our second humla workshop on Advanced Application Security Testing with Burp Pro by Sven. Please register ( required ) using below link for the workshop. As this event is hands-on, we can accommodate only few selected participants. If you get selected, you will receive a mail from humla champion by 20th July 2015. Register link: http://advancedburphumla.eventbrite.com Agenda: a) General Tips and Tricks b) Burp Collaborator explained in detail c) Creating and Handling of Macros / Session Handling Rules d) Tips and Tricks discovered during pentest engagements (e.g. circumvent transaction based CSRF tokens when using Active Scan of Burp) e) Using Burp Extensions (No development) Who should attend: Everybody that is interested in Penetration testing with Burp Suite Professional. The workshop will not explain Burp 101, therefore basic experience in Burp is highly recommended. What should I bring with me: Your own laptop, with latest version of Burp Suite Professional [masked] at the moment). If you only have Burp Suite Free Edition, not all exercises can be fully covered. Null humla champion: Sven Schleier is an Assistant Manager within KPMG Management Consulting (MC) Singapore and an experienced IT-Consultant in the field of Information Security, specialized in penetration testing of complex web applications. He is a Unix (and VIM) enthusiast since 1999 and was using Net|Free|Open-BSD heavily in his freelancer time back in Germany. When he is not at work he is spending time with his 2 year old daughter and cannot wait till she is old enough to build their first robot together and code some AI. Please reach out to humla champion at [masked] if you have any questions regarding the event.
events.location: Conference room “Blubox II” (20th floor), Hong Leon Building, 16 Raffles Quay, near Lau Pa Sat, Singapore
events.group_name: Null Singapore - The Open Security Community

events.name: DataLearn: Earth Hour + HOME DataDive Sharing
events.description: In late April, we held a DataDive where our volunteers spent a weekend to deliver data solutions for Earth Hour and HOME. This DataLearn event will include several of the participants of the DataDive sharing the methods and techniques they had used during the DataDive. The objective of the session is to get the overall community even better prepared for our next DataDive. It will be a relaxed overview from different people, and at the end we'll have a discussion on what you want to see in future DataLearn sessions. Date : 23 Jul (Thu) Time : Registration starts from 6.45pm (Event starts at 7pm) Special Thanks to our supporter PayPal Singapore for their generous food and venue sponsorship! Pizza will be served at the event. Format • 70 minutes sharing on Earth Hour • 70 minutes sharing on HOME • Questions are encouraged throughout the sharing sessions, and we'll end with a 15-20 minute discussion on what you want to see in future DataLearn sessions • No data will be shared; only sharing of methods and techniques Registration (ACTION NEEDED) Besides signing up on this meetup event, you are required to provide your particulars on this Google form for building security purposes. If we reach the event capacity, we'll be giving priority to people who were at the DataDive. See you there!
events.location: PayPal Singapore, 5 Temasek Boulevard, Level 9, Suntec Tower 5, Singapore 038985

events.name: Technical Workshop: Solar Thermal Cooling in Data Center (also avail on Webinar)
events.description: About the Trainer Mr. Harald Blazek has been with SOLID since 2008 and is currently in charge of Strategic Business Development & Marketing. SOLID is currently one of the leading system integrator for Large Scale Solar Thermal (LST) installations and has worldwide experience in designing, installing & commissioning LST systems adapted to local climates that have not a single failed system in more than 250 installations during the past 2 decades. Harald has over 7 years experience as a speaker on different international conferences and also held various trainings on Solar Thermal topics in Europe & Africa. He has also recently completed a six month stint in Singapore as the Head of SOLID’s Research & Development Team which jointly established a Solar Thermal research laboratory with Energy Research Institute @ Nanyang Technological University (ERI@N). About the Workshop: Singapore is a small city-state without natural resources such as oil and natural gas. Fortunately, we are blessed with plenty of sunshine throughout the year. When adopting a renewal solar energy system, a Large scale Solar Thermal (LST) system helps to reduce the use of fossil fuels and improves the building environmental performance. LST systems which convert the Free & Sustainable Solar Energy from the Sun to produce energy in the form of (Solar Thermal) Heat are designed to provide energy input directly to meet the local consumer’s energy requirement. Hence, a LST system helps not only to reduce the reliance on the conventional energy inputs, ie. electricity and natural gas, but could also be independent & enjoy security from any future dramatic changes in oil prices. Singapore is also a land scarce country and the optimization of available spaces is of utmost importance when evaluating the adoption of the most technologically feasible and economically viable renewable energy system. Apart from being more efficient in harvesting solar energy as compared to other alternatives, a LST system is very simple to operate and has a long operating life requiring minimum maintenance thus making a LST system an attractive renewable system that is able to optimize the use of space in Singapore. A LST system will also make the building unique and further enhances the owner’s Clean & Green image. Apart from various attractive project financing schemes from banks & other international financial institution at competitive rates, aspiring LST system end-users could tap into the alternative Energy Service Contracting (ESCo) option that offer minimum upfront investments. An ESCo is structured as a service that not only reduce operating costs & transfer risk but also allow building owners to concentrate attention on their core activities. Many aspiring LST systems owners find themselves poorly prepared when requesting system proposals and evaluating offers, as they might have little or no prior experience of LST systems and what levels of payback and incentive schemes apply. Hence, two experienced Solar Thermal industry professionals are invited to clear your doubts. Objectives of the workshop: At the end of the programme, participants will understand: • the fundamentals of Solar Thermal technology • the difference between Solar Thermal and Solar PV technologies • the possibilities and limitations of Solar Thermal applications in Data Center and Commercial buildings. • the economics and payback of Large Scale Solar Thermal (LST) systems • how to specify and evaluate LST project proposals Target Audience • Data Center Facility Managers • Building owners • Developers • Architects • Contractors • Government agencies Programme Outline The half-day workshop will comprise a mix of presentations and interactive discussions: 1. Technical Topics • Introduction and overview of Solar Thermal Technology and Large Scale Solar Thermal System • Comparison large scale vs small scale, flat plate vs tube • Comparison between Solar Thermal and PV – relevance to land scarce country like Singapore • Applications: Data Center, Commercial Solar Cooling 2. Project Evaluation • Economics and LCOE/ROI analysis • Project Financing • ESCo • Identifying and evaluating projects • Maintenance requirements and programmes 3. Q&A Session & General Discussions
events.location: Datwyler, 30 Toh Guan Road #01-01A (Opp IMM, near Furniture Mall).  , Singapore

events.name: A look at IP issues arising from 3D printing
events.description: Did you know what implications you would face when downloading a 3D model to print? Come hear from a practicing IP lawyer and join us for a day of 3D printing, scanning, and networking over food. Cheers.
events.location: Hackerspace, 344B King George's Avenue, Singapore

events.name: Conversations: Creating New Realities, Animation Now and Next
events.description: Saturday 25th July 2015 11.00am to 5.30pm ArtScience Museum, Level 4 FREE Creating New Realities: Animation Now and Next Celebrating DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition at ArtScience Museum, this event invites animators and animation thought-leaders to reflect on animation and storytelling. A panel of Singaporean thought-leaders in the field will share their own insights and present the latest innovations in animation, and consider how animation might develop and change in the future. Organized in partnership with the Singapore Film Society. Programme 11.00am - Opening and Welcome address by Honor Harger, ArtScience Museum and Chris Shaw, LaSalle College of the Arts (Chair). Talk 1: 11.10am - The Challenge of Dreaming in the Animation World. Speaker - Jacques Frety, Nanyang Polytechnic. Since its creation, Animation has always been fascinated with imaginary characters and worlds, with the public more and more trained to the new technologies of images, how will the artists continue to make us dream. Talk 2: 11.50am - Character Animation: from hyper real to stylized, defining worlds. Speaker - Juan Jose Guiraldes, Senior Animator This talk will be centered around various examples, both of fully CG films, all the way to the most popular VFX films, and how the use of character animation is used in the creation of these complex and rich worlds. Also, how the use of motion capture can help this art form to reach new heights when it is used correctly. 12.30pm – 1.30pm - Lunch Break Talk 3: 1.30pm – Finding Stories and Identity through Animation: A Singaporean Perspective. Speaker - Ervin Han, Robot Playground Media A look at how animation can be used as a storytelling tool for education and forging national identity across different generations. Talk 4: 2.10pm – Music And Sound In Animation. Speaker - Alex Oh, Film Composer The role of music and sound in animation and how it creates a 'reality'. 2.50 – Tea Break Talk 5: 3.05pm – Growing an Animation Festival today for tomorrow’s audience. Speaker - Vicky Chen, Cartoons Underground Learn how to build a community and platform for young talents to connect with a large audience and experienced leaders. 3.45pm – 4.15pm – Panel discussion, all Speakers moderated by Chair. 4.15pm – Closing remarks from Honor and Chair, Chris Shaw. 4.30pm – Tour of DreamWorks Exhibition, delivered by Honor Harger, ArtScience Museum 5.30pm – Event ends.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Asia Pacific Virtual Reality Network (Singapore Base)
events.description: The APVRN strives to connect all virtual reality meetups within the Asia Pacific region to form a single network, which provides support and education to local communities. The ultimate goal of this network is to aid local indie VR developers in creating and monetizing their content, and to act as a resource and hub for the local public who wish to engage in virtual reality technology. For Singapore, we will be hosting this meetup in a physical location and link up to Asia Pacific VR network. Do bring your oculus rift with you to experience the meetup with other VR groups in Asia Pacific region. We will be projecting the APVPN via projector. So it is alright if you come in without Oculus Rift. Date: 25th of July Time: The event is estimated to go for 4 hours List of networked meetups; Manila, Philippines: 4pm (has speakers) Shanghai: 4pm (has speakers) Brisbane, Australia: 6pm (has speakers) Istanbul, Turkey: 11am (has speakers) Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia: 4pm Abu Dhabi, UAE: 12pm Indonesia: Singapore: 4pm Timeline: 0:00 - Arrive and setup for the event - Singapore Base will be providing some small nibbles. 1:00 - Brisbane has two speakers present for 30 min each 1:30 - Istanbul has two speakers for 30 min each 2:00 - Shanghai has two speakers for 30 min each 2:30 - Philippines has two speakers for 30 min each List speaker presenting + topics: Lex Van Cooten (Brisbane) - Opening Remarks Sami Hamid (Istanbul) - ‘Will VR Work This Time?’ Richard Huang - Preserving History in VR Cristopher David - VR adoption in the developing world. Wilf Watson (Brisbane) - Open Source Mobile VR Project NOTE: (If possible) There should be VR booths (connected to the internet) setup away from the presentation area where meetup attendees may log in to VRChat/ConVRge to socialise with other individuals who have logged in from around the world. Meetup Details Asia Pacific VR Network: www.apvrn.com Brisbane, Australia: www.virtualrealitybrisbane.com Abu Dhabi, UAE: www.meetup.com/abu-dhabi-vr Singapore: www. meetup.com/sgvrar Singapore Base of Asia Pacific VR network is supported by TechHub@NUS .
events.location: TechHub (The Glass house), Engineering Workshop 2, 1 Engineering Drive 3, S117580, Singapore

events.name: Conversations: “~sound:senses”
events.description: “~sound:senses” Saturday 22nd August 2015 2.15pm to 5.30pm ArtScience Museum, Level 4 FREE What is the colour of sound? Does the shape of the plate change the taste of the cake? This August, join us as leading artists and scientists in the fields of psychology, sound art, perception, and multimodal design come together to explore how sound acts as the glue connecting our sensorial experiences and interactions. Guest speakers include luminaries such as interaction designer, Stefania Serafin, crossmodality researcher Charles Spence, composer Joyce Beetuan Koh, filmmaker Daniel Belton, and psycholinguist Suzy Styles. Chairing the panel is ArtScience Museum Executive Director, Honor Harger. Closing the event is Black Zenith, who will be performing Microsaccades; a culmination of sound, live visuals and video. The event is part of the Soundislands Festival, initiated by PerMagnus Lindborg with support from CLASS and ADM at Nanyang Technological University, the Italian Institute of Culture, and the Arts Council of New Zealand.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Sunday Showcase
events.description: Sunday Showcase allows visitors unique access to cutting edge projects being undertaken by different tertiary institutions across Singapore. The series invites the creators and their work into ArtScience Museum on a Sunday each month. The creators are on hand throughout the afternoon to talk with visitors about their inventions, their creative process, and to facilitate visitors' interaction with the projects. There is something for everyone in this hands-on, accessible showcase series. Sunday 23rd August 2015 10am to 6.30pm ArtScience Museum, Level 4 FREE “~sound:senses” Sound is the medium that acts as the glue between the senses, intertwining hearing, vision and movement. This Sunday Showcase, we invite you to dive into a coral reef of artworks and scientific demonstrations by international artists and researchers who have mapped out crossmodal associations with touch, smell, feel, and taste. “~sound:senses” will feature sound installations, experimental films, robotic sculptures, mobile media, web audio solutions, as well as workshops on electroacoustic sounds led by experts. The event is part of the Soundislands Festival, with support from Nanyang Technological University.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Papers We Love #012
events.description: Paper #1 - something something dark side : Laurence Day Paper #2 - Robust Range-Only Beacon Localization : Ashish Raste - https://people.csail.mit.edu/teller/pubs/robl.pdf ------------------- What was the last paper within the realm of computing/technology you read and loved? What did it inspire you to build or tinker with? Come share the ideas in an awesome academic/research paper with fellow engineers, programmers, and paper-readers. Lead a session and show off code that you wrote that implements these ideas or just give us the lowdown about the paper (because of HARD MATH!). Otherwise, just come, listen, and discuss. ----------------- Original Meetup : http://www.meetup.com/papers-we-love Papers Repo : https://github.com/papers-we-love/papers-we-love Code of Conduct : https://github.com/papers-we-love/papers-we-love/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
events.location: HackerspaceSG

events.name: A look at Ways To Monetize Your 3D Printing Hobby
events.description: Wondering how to get started on your 3D printing? Maybe you have started on a 3D model and making your first 3D printed products, but you haven't got a clue how to make money from it? Hear from our guest artists who will share with you their practical tips and experiences! Join us for a few hours of 3D printing and scanning over some finger food too. Sign up early - we can only take about 20 people. See you folks!
events.location: Hackerspace, 344B King George's Avenue, Singapore

events.name: The PowerShell Conference 2015, Asia
events.description: PowerShell Conference Asia 2015 is coming up fast so here’s a quick update on all the incredible speakers we’ve got lined up already. After we sent out the call for Speakers and Sponsors we had an awesome response. We’ve had Community Members, MVPs and even the PowerShell Product Team put their hand up to be there and present the latest and greatest in PowerShell to you. Now that we’re rapidly approaching the second half of the year a lot of people have been contacting us keen to know how they can register. We’ve been really overwhelmed with interest and support from the whole APAC Community, so thank you for that. Here’s an overview of the current arrangements and plans Platinum Sponsor We are extremely pleased to announce officially that SAPIEN Technologies are going to be our platinum sponsor for this event! SAPIEN have long supported the PowerShell community and make some of the best tools on the market. With amazing folks like David Corales, Ferdinand Rios and June Blender, SAPIEN are hugely influential in the PowerShell community, we can't thank them enough for helping to make this event happen. SAPIEN will be present for both days and we look forward to welcoming them. If you can arrange to stay an extra day you’ll be able to experience the excitement of the Singapore F1 Grand Prix. What a way to wrap up the week! What about Registration? Registration: We have opened up Registration on EventBrite and you can find it here: https://www.eventbrite.sg/e/powershell-conference-asia-2015-tickets-17336891108 We are accepting payment by PayPal and registration is not confirmed until payment is made. For this awesome event we are asking a US$200 registration fee. So what do you get for your money? • 2 full days of intense sessions with international speakers • Breakfast, lunch and afternoon tea on both days • T-Shirt and sponsor giveaways • Entry to the Closing Party on Saturday evening (food & drinks included) • Connect with other PowerShell enthusiasts in the region • Network with peers, MVPs, speakers and the PowerShell Team! If you have any questions or need help arranging travel and accommodation details please let us know. We’re really excited to see you all there in September. ** DISCLAIMER **: By registering through MeetUp is just an indicative on knowing which peers will be attending within the group which will be beneficial to learn together. You will need to register through EventBrite and have the confirmation email before you are allow in the event! Lastly, we have limited seats! So do hurry up!
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989
